content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Awesome use of data structures

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: fun and hard
In my opinion, the problem is a tiny bit too hard for a Clash of code.

Very interesting !
Maybe you could add a case with a "Division by 0"?
Thanks for the suggestion. I added the case.

Well, I think it is more interesting with a division by zero as it is currently, but maybe I could make it slightly simpler by removing this requirement again and instead mentioning somehow in the *constraints* section that there will be no division by zero? Would it make the problem considerably simpler for a CoC in your opinion or there is no difference?

I don't think that would be better, the complexity comes from : reversing the string, and using a stack with function pointer array (or eval if available in the language). It's not that the algorithme is hard to write, but it is hard to find.
imo, you can make it more complex (for instance by adding modulo[%] and power[^]) and propose it as a solo puzzle.

Reversing the string is not a requirement as such, neither is using a stack, it is just my solution. It was simply easier for me to reverse the string and solve this way, but someone may prefer to solve without reversing the string, or without using a stack and so on, I guess my solution which is given here should not be the only possible solution or even the best one or simplest one either.

by the way, as a matter of fact, strictly speaking even in my solution there is no string reversal at all, in the given solution I reverse a list that I get AFTER splitting the string, if you reverse directly the given string then it will not work, for example number 21 would become 12 and so on...

I think it is currently very hard for a clash of code. I tried it and the division by 0 took me half of the time to solve it. I would recommand to specify that there will be no division by 0 and that all results will stay integer at all time, instead of rounding to the nearest integer
